general_tips: Use action verbs to start bullet points (Led, Developed, Implemented, Designed, Optimized)
Quantify achievements with specific metrics (percentages, dollar amounts, user numbers)
Tailor resume to each job posting by matching keywords
Use consistent formatting and professional fonts
Add links to GitHub, LinkedIn, and portfolio
technical_skills: Group skills by category (Languages, Frameworks, Tools, Databases)
List proficiency levels for key technologies
Include both technical and soft skills
Prioritize skills mentioned in job description
Update skills section regularly with new technologies
experience_section: Use reverse chronological order (most recent first)
Include company name, location, job title, and dates
Focus on accomplishments, not just responsibilities
Use the STAR method (Situation, Task, Action, Result)
quantifiable_achievements: Performance improvements: 'Optimized queries reducing response time by 45%'
Cost savings: 'Reduced cloud infrastructure costs by $50K annually'
User impact: 'Improved user experience for 100K+ users'
common_mistakes: Using passive voice instead of active voice
Listing job duties instead of achievements
Not customizing resume for each application
ats_optimization: Use standard section headings (Experience, Education, Skills)
Include keywords from job description naturally
Avoid images, tables, and complex formatting
Use standard fonts (Arial, Calibri, Times New Roman)
Spell out acronyms at least once

software_engineer: Include GitHub contributions and personal projects
Highlight system design and architecture experience
Mention code review and mentoring activities
data_scientist: Showcase ML models and algorithms used
Highlight business impact of data insights
Mention experience with big data technologies
frontend_developer: Include portfolio link with live projects
